verses.text: Then Job answered and said:
verses.comment: Job begins his reply to his friends’ accusations. The dialogue format is a central feature of Job’s narrative.

verses.text: How long will you torment me and crush me with words?
verses.comment: Job expresses the pain caused not just by suffering, but by the wounds of harsh speech. The impact of words is repeatedly recognized in scripture.

verses.text: These ten times you have insulted me; you are not ashamed to wrong me.
verses.comment: ‘Ten times’ is a Hebrew idiom for repeated suffering. Job calls out the persistence of the injustice he perceives.

verses.text: If indeed I have erred, my error remains with me.
verses.comment: Job defends his integrity but admits, if he has failed, it is a matter between him and God alone. This underscores personal accountability.

verses.text: If you truly want to magnify yourselves against me and use my disgrace as evidence against me,
verses.comment: Job sees his friends as taking pleasure in his humiliation, a warning against spiritual pride.

verses.text: then know that God has wronged me and has surrounded me with His net.
verses.comment: Job wrestles with the mystery of innocent suffering, perceiving his trial as coming from God. This introduces questions of divine providence and justice.

verses.text: Behold, I cry out, ‘Violence!’ but I am not answered; I call for help, but there is no justice.
verses.comment: Job’s plea echoes the anguished prayers later uttered by the suffering Messiah, foreshadowing Christ’s own abandonment (see Psalm 22).

verses.text: He has walled up my way, so I cannot pass; He has set darkness upon my paths.
verses.comment: God’s action is seen as limiting Job’s freedom, a motif that recurs when the faithful encounter trials and spiritual darkness.

verses.text: He has stripped my glory from me and removed the crown from my head.
verses.comment: Job’s loss is depicted as a stripping away of dignity and honor. The crown’s removal foreshadows the humility and suffering embraced by Christ.

verses.text: He breaks me down on every side, and I am gone; He uproots my hope like a tree.
verses.comment: Images of destruction and hopelessness are used here, yet the tree metaphor recalls eventual restoration, a theme later developed in scripture.

verses.text: He has kindled His anger against me and considers me as one of His enemies.
verses.comment: God’s wrath is perceived by Job, aligning with David’s experiences when chastened, hinting at the complexity of divine justice towards those He loves.

verses.text: His troops come together and build up their siege ramp against me; they encamp around my tent.
verses.comment: Job uses the imagery of an army besieging a city to describe his suffering, reminiscent of the spiritual battles faced by the faithful.

verses.text: He has removed my family far from me, and my acquaintances are completely estranged.
verses.comment: Isolation is a recurring theme for Job and is found in the Psalms as well, hinting toward the reality that spiritual struggle often involves loneliness.

verses.text: My relatives have deserted me, and my close friends have forgotten me.
verses.comment: Job’s abandonment by loved ones reflects a theme that will later appear in the life of Christ (cf. Mark 14:50), suggesting a typology between Job and Jesus.

verses.text: Those who dwell in my house and my maids regard me as a stranger; I am an alien in their eyes.
verses.comment: Even those obligated to love and serve Job have turned away, emphasizing the complete rejection he endures.

verses.text: I call my servant, but he does not answer; I must plead with him with my mouth.
verses.comment: Job’s reference to pleading with a servant furthers the indignity, reminiscent of the reversal of fortunes described elsewhere in Wisdom literature.

verses.text: My breath is offensive to my wife, and I am repulsive to the children of my own body.
verses.comment: Job’s suffering extends even to his closest relationships. Marital and familial love is tested, recalling how suffering can sanctify and purify human relationships.

verses.text: Even young children despise me; when I arise, they speak against me.
verses.comment: Complete rejection, even by children, fulfills the fullness of suffering endured by Job and strengthens the parallel to Christ, who too was despised.

verses.text: All my close friends abhor me, and those whom I loved have turned against me.
verses.comment: Betrayal by friends and loved ones is a universal sorrow, prefiguring Jesus’s betrayal by Judas and abandonment by the disciples.

verses.text: My bones cling to my skin and flesh, and I have escaped only by the skin of my teeth.
verses.comment: A vivid image of physical suffering, showing Job’s near escape from death. The idiom ‘skin of my teeth’ originates here.

verses.text: Have mercy on me, have mercy, O my friends, for the hand of God has struck me.
verses.comment: Job’s plea for mercy sets a model for compassion among the faithful, anticipating the Christian call to share in one another’s burdens.

verses.text: Why do you pursue me as God does? Are you not satisfied with my flesh?
verses.comment: Job equates the relentless attacks of his friends with divine retribution, questioning the purpose of extra human cruelty.

verses.text: Oh, that my words were written! Oh, that they were inscribed in a book!
verses.comment: Job wishes his testimony were preserved forever, foreshadowing the permanence of divine revelation and the scriptural tradition.

verses.text: That with an iron stylus and lead they were engraved in the rock forever!
verses.comment: Job yearns for permanence to his defense, anticipating the perpetual nature of Scripture as enduring witness for all generations.

verses.text: For I know that my Redeemer lives, and at the last He will stand upon the earth.
verses.comment: A profound declaration of faith in a living Redeemer, which Christians understand as a prophecy of Christ’s resurrection and victory over death. Both literal (Job trusts God’s final vindication) and spiritual (foretells Christ’s standing in judgement).

verses.text: And after my skin has been destroyed, yet in my flesh I shall see God,
verses.comment: Job’s hope of resurrection and seeing God in his flesh illuminates the doctrine of bodily resurrection, later fulfilled in Christ’s rising and the hope of all believers.

verses.text: Whom I myself shall see, and my eyes shall behold, and not another. My heart longs within me.
verses.comment: This personal vision of God stems from a deep desire for union with the divine, echoing the beatitudes’ promise that the pure in heart will see God.

verses.text: If you say, ‘How will we pursue him?’ and, ‘The root of the matter is found in him,’
verses.comment: Job challenges others’ judgment, emphasizing that the cause of his suffering lies beyond human understanding—a call to humility in interpreting divine mysteries.

verses.text: be afraid of the sword, for wrath brings the punishment of the sword, so that you may know there is judgment.
verses.comment: Job warns against unjust condemnation, declaring that judgment ultimately belongs to God alone. This points toward the understanding of divine justice and last things.
